> I see no need to test methods other than public <snip> I'll write 

 > test methods for the protected methods as well.

So why do you test protected methods if there's no need to test methods 
other than public?  Simply because it depends.  Sometimes you want to 
test protected methods, sometimes you don't.

My point is: placing tests classes so that it is _impossible_ to test 
protected methods is a "bad" decision because you restrict your 
flexibility.  By placing test classes in the same package, you still 
have that flexibility, but you don't have to use it if you don't want to.

- Vladimir
